questions.text: Which of the following is a selective alpha 1 receptor antagonist?
questions.solution:
Prazosin is a sympatholytic drug that is a selective α1 receptor antagonist.

The sympatholytics are classified into α and β-blockers.


Miscellaneous antiadrenergic drugs that inhibit synthesis or release of neurotransmitters include:

  • Metyrosine
  • Reserpine
  • Tetrabenazine
  • Deutetrabenazine

questions.text: Which of the following is an incorrect statement regarding prazosin?

choices.text: Blocks all subtypes of alpha 1 receptors
It is only an arteriolar dilator
It has a beneficial effect on lipid profile

questions.solution:
Prazosin causes dilation of both arterioles and veins. 

As a result, both afterload and preload decrease. However, the reflex tachycardia is less pronounced due to the absence of α2 blockade.

Prazosin blocks all subtypes of the α1 receptor (α1A, α1B, and α1D). It also has a beneficial effect on lipid profile as it decreases LDL and triglycerides and increases HDL levels.

questions.text: In which of the following patients would prazosin not be used therapeutically?
questions.solution:
Prazosin is not useful to treat a patient with ejaculatory dysfunction. It is indicated in relieving symptoms of benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH).

Prazosin is an α1 receptor antagonist and is useful in:

  • Relieving vasospasm in peripheral vascular diseases 
  • Controlling the symptoms of pheochromocytoma preoperatively (as an alternative to phenoxybenzamine)
  • Mainstay treatment for scorpion sting along with antivenom

questions.text: A patient presents with complaints of dizziness while getting up from bed. He tells you he was recently diagnosed with BPH and has been taking prazosin. Which of the following drugs would be a good replacement for him?
questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of postural hypotension caused by prazosin. These symptoms can be avoided by using silodosin which has a selective antagonist action on α1A receptors over α1B receptors.

The prostate stroma has a maximum concentration of α1A receptors over other α1 receptor subtypes. α1B receptors are present on blood vessels which play a role in vasoconstriction. Hence, selective α1A receptor antagonists have minimal effect on blood pressure as compared to non-selective α1 antagonists like prazosin.

α1 receptor antagonists can be classified as:

  • Selective antagonists
    • Silodosin (α1A)
    • Tamsulosin (α1A + α1D)
  • Non-selective 
    • Prazosin
    • Terazosin
    • Doxazosin
    • Alfuzosin

questions.text: A 62-year-old male presents with complaints of a weak urine stream and frequent urination in small amounts for the past month. He also mentions that he often feels lightheaded and has low blood pressure. Which of the following alpha-blockers will you prefer to give him?
questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) and tamsulosin should be given to this patient as it has the least effect on blood pressure. 

It is an α-blocker that has more selectivity towards α1A/1D when compared to α1B receptors. The vasodilatory effects are mainly attributed to the blockade of α1B receptors present on blood vessels.

The relief of BPH symptoms is mainly due to the blockade of α1A receptors present predominantly in the prostatic stroma. It lacks the apoptotic effect on prostatic cells that is seen with terazosin and doxazosin.

questions.text: You prescribe tamsulosin to a patient with benign prostatic hyperplasia. What is the main side effect that should be explained to the patient?
questions.solution:
Retrograde ejaculation is the main side effect of tamsulosin. 

It is a selective α1A/1D blocker and the relief of BPH symptoms is mainly due to blockade of α1A receptors. Blockade of α1D receptors present in the bladder relaxes the urethral sphincter, which is normally closed during ejaculation. This results in the redirection of semen into the urinary bladder.

Silodosin causes ejaculatory dysfunction due to absence of seminal emission.

questions.text: Which of the following is a selective alpha 2 receptor antagonist?
questions.solution:
Yohimbine is a competitive antagonist that is selective for α2 receptors. It was earlier used in the indication of erectile dysfunction but is rarely indicated now due to better results with PDE5 inhibitors.

Terazosin and alfuzosin are selective alpha 1 receptor antagonists.

Yasmin (drospirenone) is a 4th generation progestin used as an oral contraceptive having mineralocorticoid antagonist action.

questions.text: Phenoxybenzamine is indicated in the management of which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Phenoxybenzamine is indicated in the preoperative preparation of patients with pheochromocytoma. It is also indicated for symptomatic control in inoperable and advanced pheochromocytoma.

Option B: Phenoxybenzamine is not used in the management of essential hypertension because of the irreversible alpha blockade and increased risk of adverse effects.

Option C: For erectile dysfunction, intracavernous phentolamine, a reversible non-selective alpha-blocker is indicated.

questions.text: A patient with erectile dysfunction complained of unsatisfactory response to oral medication. He was then administered an intracavernosal injection of phentolamine following which he developed sustained painful erection. Which of the following can be used to reverse his condition?
questions.solution:
The reversal of phentolamine induced priapism (painful erection) can be achieved by intracavernosal injection of phenylephrine.

Intracavernosal phentolamine (α-blocker) is used for the management of impotency. Priapism is a serious adverse effect of this agent. Phenylephrine is an α agonist and counteracts phentolamine induced priapism by producing vasoconstriction.

Phentolamine is useful in:

  • Hypertensive crisis due to clonidine withdrawal
  • Short term control of intra-operative hypertension in patients with pheochromocytoma
  • MAO inhibitor-induced hypertension in cheese reaction

Options A and B: Phenoxybenzamine and prazosin are α-receptor antagonists and can worsen priapism.

Option D: Propranolol is a non-selective β-blocker and is not indicated in this condition.

questions.text: In which of the following conditions is propanolol not indicated?
questions.solution:
Propranolol is not indicated in variant angina. It can cause further constriction of coronary arteries by leaving alpha-mediated coronary vasoconstriction unopposed.

Uses of propranolol include:

  • Management of thyrotoxicosis
  • Management of hypertension (however, cardioselective beta-blockers are now preferred over non-selective)
  • Treatment of infantile hemangioma
  • Management of essential tremors and panic attacks
  • Prophylaxis of migraine
  • Prevention of variceal bleeding in portal hypertension

questions.text: A 45-year-old man is diagnosed with type 2 diabetes mellitus during a routine health evaluation. He mentions that he is on propranolol for essential tremors. You would caution him against continuing the drug due to what reason?
questions.solution:
Propranolol is generally avoided in diabetic patients because it masks the hypoglycaemic symptoms.

Non-selective β blockers interfere with the counter-regulatory hormones secreted during hypoglycemia, resulting in prolonged hypoglycemia. It also decreases the perception of symptoms such as tremors, tachycardia, and nervousness. These symptoms are manifested due to stimulation of sympathetic beta receptors in response to hypoglycemia. Blunting of sympathetic response results in hypoglycemic unawareness. 

Cardioselective beta-blockers have relatively lesser interference on the sympathetic response to hypoglycemia and are preferred in diabetic patients.

questions.text: Propranolol is drug of choice for:
questions.solution:
Propranolol is the drug of choice in the management of infantile hemangioma complicated by ulceration or in symptomatic patients. 

It acts by causing vasoconstriction, inducing apoptosis and inhibition of angiogenesis.

questions.text: Which of the following is a cardioselective beta blocker with antioxidant property?
questions.solution:
Nebivolol is a cardioselective beta-blocker with additional antioxidant property.

Nebivolol:

  • Nebivolol is a third-generation, long-acting, and highly selective β1 adrenergic receptor antagonist
  • It stimulates NO-mediated vasodilation via β3 receptor agonism
  • Nebivolol is approved for the treatment of hypertension
  • It has potential utility in the treatment of heart failure with reduced ejection fraction
  • Nebivolol reduces oxidative stress and may have favorable effects on both carbohydrate and lipid metabolism
  • This can be used in metabolic syndrome.

questions.text:
Esmolol is indicated in which of the following conditions?
  1. Intraoperative tachycardia
  2. Postoperative hypertension
  3. Supraventricular tachycardia
  4. Pulmonary hypertension
  5. Hypertensive emergency
questions.solution:
Esmolol is a short-acting cardioselective beta-blocker that is indicated in:

  • Prevention and management of intraoperative tachycardia
  • Postoperative hypertension
  • Supraventricular tachycardia
  • Hypertensive emergency

It is contraindicated in pulmonary hypertension.

questions.text: Which of the following is a false statement?

choices.text: Metoprolol prolongs survival in congestive cardiac failure
Esmolol is mainly metabolised in the liver

questions.solution:
Esmolol contains an ester linkage and it is hydrolyzed rapidly by esterases in erythrocytes and not in the liver. This results in a short half-life of about 8-10 minutes.

It is used in the management of intraoperative and postoperative hypertension as it has a short duration of action and can be discontinued quickly.

Option A: Metoprolol is approved for use in chronic congestive cardiac failure and has shown mortality benefit.

Option B: Celiprolol has shown a relaxant effect on vascular smooth muscle and weak vasodilation due to partial selective β2 agonism.

Option D: Nebivolol has the additional action of releasing nitric oxide.

questions.text: Identify the third-generation beta-blocker that does not cause alpha 1 receptor antagonism.
questions.solution:
Celiprolol is a third-generation beta blocker having no action on α1 receptors. It causes vasodilation by partial selective β2 agonist activity.

Labetalol, carvedilol, and bucindolol are non-selective third-generation beta blockers that possess additional α1 receptor antagonistic action. This is responsible for their vasodilatory effect.

Note: Third-generation β-blockers are those that possess additional vasodilating actions and include cardioselective and non-selective drugs.

questions.text: You are about to add a beta-blocker to the treatment chart of a patient with heart failure. Which of the following is not true about the use of these drugs in this condition?

choices.text: Most effective in acute decompensated heart failure
Should be started at a low dose
Carvedilol is widely used in this condition

questions.solution:
β-blockers are contraindicated in the treatment of acute decompensated heart failure (ADHF) as they can worsen the condition. They are indicated only in patients with chronic stable heart failure.

Option A: Though contraindicated in ADHF, it is safe to start once the patient is euvolemic. Initiation of β-blocker prior to discharge is associated with improved outcomes and must be continued after discharge.

Option C: β-blockers are initiated at a low dose and slowly titrated to decrease the risk of precipitating heart failure.

Option D: Carvedilol has been shown to reduce mortality in patients with heart failure, and is widely used because of additional benefits like antioxidant properties and peripheral vasodilatory action.

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about beta-blockers?

choices.text: Atenolol is longer acting than metoprolol
Labetalol has both alpha and beta blocking action

questions.solution:
Celiprolol is excreted predominantly through the renal route. It is excreted unchanged in the urine.

Option A: Atenolol is longer acting with a longer half-life than metoprolol. It is usually administered once daily.

Option C: Labetalol is a non-selective β-blocker with α1 blocking action similar to carvedilol.

Option D: Nadolol has the longest half-life of 20 hours and is administered once daily.

questions.text: A nurse in the nephrology ward is managing the drug inventory for patients with severe renal failure. Which of the following beta-blockers is least likely to be present in the drug charts?
questions.solution:
Sotalol is least likely to be present in the treatment charts as it is contraindicated in severe renal failure. It has low lipid solubility and is excreted primarily unchanged in the urine.

Carvedilol, metoprolol and labetalol are metabolised by the liver and can be used in renal failure.

questions.text: Beta-blockers are not indicated in which of the following patients?
questions.solution:
Beta-blockers are not indicated in hypothyroidism. They are indicated in hyperthyroidism and thyrotoxicosis that manifests with increased sympathetic activity.

Options B and C: Beta-blockers are useful in the treatment of alcohol withdrawal and in reducing variceal bleeding in portal hypertension.

Option D: β blockers like propranolol are effective in controlling acute panic symptoms and anxiety associated with performing in public. They reduce symptoms of increased sympathetic activity such as tachycardia and tremors.

questions.text: Which of the following is a selective beta 2 antagonist?
questions.solution:
Butoxamine is a selective β2 antagonist.

There are no clinical indications currently for selective β2 antagonists and they are still being researched.

questions.text: Cocaine-like effect of inhibiting neuronal uptake of noradrenaline is seen with which of the following?
questions.solution:
Cocaine-like effect of inhibiting neuronal uptake of noradrenaline (NE) is seen with labetalol.

It is a third-generation non-selective β blocker with the following actions:

  • Non-selective β receptor blockade
  • Selective α1 receptor blockade
  • Inhibition of neuronal uptake of NE/cocaine-like effect

questions.text:
Match the following beta-blockers with their receptor selectivity and additional actions.
A. Pindolol  1. Non-selective, antioxidant
B. Carvedilol  2. Non-selective, intrinsic agonist
C.Betaxolol  3. Beta 1 selective, intrinsic agonist
D.Acebutolol  4. Beta 1 selective, membrane stabilizing
questions.solution:
Pindolol  Non-selective, intrinsic agonist
Carvedilol  Non-selective, antioxidant
Betaxolol  Beta 1 selective, membrane stabilizing
Acebutolol  Beta 1 selective, intrinsic agonist

Pindolol is a non-selective first-generation β-blocker with significant intrinsic agonist activity, which may result in a smaller reduction in heart rate and blood pressure. This is useful in patients with diminished cardiac reserve or at risk of bradycardia.

Carvedilol is a non-selective third-generation β-blocker with antioxidant and anti-inflammatory properties. These properties make it useful in the treatment of congestive heart failure.

Betaxolol is a β1 selective third-generation β-blocker with additional calcium entry blockade activity and a slight membrane-stabilizing property. It does not have agonist activity.

Acebutolol is a β1 selective second-generation β blocker having both membrane-stabilizing and intrinsic agonist activity. It is useful in the treatment of atrial and ventricular arrhythmias.
